data.title: Oakville's Lauren Holly front and centre in 'Tiny Pretty Things'
data.meta_description: Lauren Holly’s buzzy new Netflix ballet drama,
data.text:
Reviews and recommendations are unbiased and products are independently selected. Postmedia may earn an affiliate commission from purchases made through links on this page.

Article content

Lauren Holly’s buzzy new Netflix ballet drama, Tiny Pretty Things — available for streaming Monday — was easier logistically than most gigs for the actress known for her roles in Picket Fences, Dumb and Dumber and All My Children.

Article content

That’s because the 57-year-old American-born Holly moved to Canada 11 years ago after marrying her third husband, Canadian investment banker Francis Greco, so the Toronto set was just a short drive away from her Oakville home.

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Try refreshing your browser, or

tap here to see other videos from our team.

Oakville's Lauren Holly front and centre in 'Tiny Pretty Things' Back to video

“For me it was fantastic actually,” said Holly, who has since divorced Greco. “Because I very rarely get to work where I live. It seems I’m always working in Vancouver. (This was) easy peasy, man. I just loved it.”

We caught up with the mother of three sons — formerly married to Canadian comedian Jim Carrey — at her Oakville residence.

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Try refreshing your browser, or

tap here to see other videos from our team.

How’s Canada suiting you and your family?

Everyone’s dual (citizenship) including me. And I decided two years ago, ‘This is stupid. I live here. I feel at home here. I’ve built a whole career here. I need to apply for my citizenship.’ And I became citizen a year ago and I was shocked how emotional the ceremony was for me. I was so happy.

Article content

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Did you shoot Tiny Pretty Things with COVID-19 protocols?

No. It was from end of July to December last year. It was perfect. And we wrapped and I took my boys on this incredible epic trip. We went to Tokyo for Christmas and Sydney Australia for New Year’s Eve. And it was just going to be just a fabulous trip. And we came back and got sick. I even wonder if we had COVID already in our house. I don’t know to tell you the truth. I’m certainly not acting like we had it and running around. I’ve been locked in my house.

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Try refreshing your browser, or

tap here to see other videos from our team.

Tiny Pretty Things is based on a young adult novel but your character, Madame Monique, who is a former prima ballerina and now the head of an elite Chicago ballet academy, was created specifically for the series. How did it feel to be No.1 on the call sheet?

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

I said to (writer-showrunner-executive producer) Michael (MacLennan), ‘Listen, I’m going to try and be the best number one that you could ever have.’ Because I had that on my first big successful show with Kathy Baker on Picket Fences (1992-1996). I’ve been doing this for 35 years and I would say this is the second time from the very first day, it just felt like there was magic dust.”

Do you expect there will be a second season then?

I don’t think we’ll know until the data comes in. So I just want everyone to watch because I want to do it again so much. I think what Netflix was saying was, if we get to go back, they said it’ll probably be like May so that (hopefully) there will be vaccines available and all that. Because between sex and dancing on this show, I’m not sure how you do it otherwise.
